trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a Node JS web app that signs users in with both personal Microsoft Account and work or school accounts.
trans-unit.target: How to build a Node JS web app that signs users in with both personal Microsoft Account and work or school accounts.

trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 Preview: Add sign-in to a nodeJS Web App
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 Preview: Add sign-in to a nodeJS Web App

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).

trans-unit.source: Here we'll use Passport to:
trans-unit.target: Here we'll use Passport to:

trans-unit.source: Sign the user into the app using Azure AD and the v2.0 app model.
trans-unit.target: Sign the user into the app using Azure AD and the v2.0 app model.

trans-unit.source: Display some information about the user.
trans-unit.target: Display some information about the user.

trans-unit.source: Sign the user out of the app.
trans-unit.target: Sign the user out of the app.

trans-unit.source: **Passport** is authentication middleware for Node.js.
trans-unit.target: **Passport** is authentication middleware for Node.js.

trans-unit.source: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.
trans-unit.target: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.

trans-unit.source: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.
trans-unit.target: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.

trans-unit.source: We have developed a strategy for Microsoft Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: We have developed a strategy for Microsoft Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: We will install this module and then add the Microsoft Azure Active Directory `passport-azure-ad` plug-in.
trans-unit.target: We will install this module and then add the Microsoft Azure Active Directory `passport-azure-ad` plug-in.

trans-unit.source: In order to do this, you'll need to:
trans-unit.target: In order to do this, you'll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register an app.
trans-unit.target: Register an app.

trans-unit.source: Set up your app to use the Passport-azure-ad strategy.
trans-unit.target: Set up your app to use the Passport-azure-ad strategy.

trans-unit.source: Use Passport to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Use Passport to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Print out data about the user.
trans-unit.target: Print out data about the user.

trans-unit.source: The code for this tutorial is maintained [on GitHub](https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebApp-OpenIDConnect-nodejs).
trans-unit.target: The code for this tutorial is maintained [on GitHub](https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebApp-OpenIDConnect-nodejs).

trans-unit.source: To follow along, you can [download the app's skeleton as a .zip](https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebApp-OpenIDConnect-nodejs/archive/skeleton.zip) or clone the skeleton:
trans-unit.target: To follow along, you can [download the app's skeleton as a .zip](https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebApp-OpenIDConnect-nodejs/archive/skeleton.zip) or clone the skeleton:

trans-unit.source: The completed application is provided at the end of this tutorial as well.
trans-unit.target: The completed application is provided at the end of this tutorial as well.

trans-unit.source: 1. Register an App
trans-unit.target: 1. Register an App

trans-unit.source: Create a new app at [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com), or follow these [detailed steps](active-directory-v2-app-registration.md).
trans-unit.target: Create a new app at [apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com), or follow these [detailed steps](active-directory-v2-app-registration.md).

trans-unit.source: Make sure to:
trans-unit.target: Make sure to:

trans-unit.source: Copy down the **Application Id** assigned to your app, you'll need it soon.
trans-unit.target: Copy down the **Application Id** assigned to your app, you'll need it soon.

trans-unit.source: Add the **Web** platform for your app.
trans-unit.target: Add the **Web** platform for your app.

trans-unit.source: Enter the correct **Redirect URI**.
trans-unit.target: Enter the correct **Redirect URI**.

trans-unit.source: The redirect URI indicates to Azure AD where authentication responses should be directed - the default for this tutorial is `http://localhost:3000/auth/openid/return`.
trans-unit.target: The redirect URI indicates to Azure AD where authentication responses should be directed - the default for this tutorial is `http://localhost:3000/auth/openid/return`.

trans-unit.source: 2. Add pre-requisities to your directory
trans-unit.target: 2. Add pre-requisities to your directory

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to your root folder if not already there and run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to your root folder if not already there and run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: In addition, we've use `passport-azure-ad` for our Preview in the skeleton of the quickstart.
trans-unit.target: In addition, we've use `passport-azure-ad` for our Preview in the skeleton of the quickstart.

trans-unit.source: This will install the libraries that passport-azure-ad depend on.
trans-unit.target: This will install the libraries that passport-azure-ad depend on.

trans-unit.source: 3. Set up your app to use the passport-node-js strategy
trans-unit.target: 3. Set up your app to use the passport-node-js strategy

trans-unit.source: Here, we'll configure the Express middleware to use the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.
trans-unit.target: Here, we'll configure the Express middleware to use the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.

trans-unit.source: Passport will be used to issue sign-in and sign-out requests, manage the user's session, and get information about the user, amongst other things.
trans-unit.target: Passport will be used to issue sign-in and sign-out requests, manage the user's session, and get information about the user, amongst other things.

trans-unit.source: To begin, open the `config.js` file in the root of the project, and enter your app's configuration values in the `exports.creds` section.
trans-unit.target: To begin, open the `config.js` file in the root of the project, and enter your app's configuration values in the `exports.creds` section.

trans-unit.source: The `clientID:` is the **Application Id** assigned to your app in the registration portal.
trans-unit.target: The `clientID:` is the **Application Id** assigned to your app in the registration portal.

trans-unit.source: The `returnURL` is the **Redirect URI** you entered in the portal.
trans-unit.target: The `returnURL` is the **Redirect URI** you entered in the portal.

trans-unit.source: The `clientSecret` is the secret you generated in the portal.
trans-unit.target: The `clientSecret` is the secret you generated in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Next open `app.js` file in the root of the proejct and add the follwing call to invoke the `OIDCStrategy` strategy that comes with `passport-azure-ad`
trans-unit.target: Next open `app.js` file in the root of the proejct and add the follwing call to invoke the `OIDCStrategy` strategy that comes with `passport-azure-ad`

trans-unit.source: After that, use the strategy we just referenced to handle our login requests
trans-unit.target: After that, use the strategy we just referenced to handle our login requests

trans-unit.source: Passport uses a similar pattern for all it’s Strategies (Twitter, Facebook, etc.) that all Strategy writers adhere to.
trans-unit.target: Passport uses a similar pattern for all it’s Strategies (Twitter, Facebook, etc.) that all Strategy writers adhere to.

trans-unit.source: Looking at the strategy you see we pass it a function() that has a token and a done as the parameters.
trans-unit.target: Looking at the strategy you see we pass it a function() that has a token and a done as the parameters.

trans-unit.source: The strategy will dutifully come back to us once it does all it’s work.
trans-unit.target: The strategy will dutifully come back to us once it does all it’s work.

trans-unit.source: Once it does we’ll want to store the user and stash the token so we won’t need to ask for it again.
trans-unit.target: Once it does we’ll want to store the user and stash the token so we won’t need to ask for it again.

trans-unit.source: The code above takes any user that happens to authenticate to our server.
trans-unit.target: The code above takes any user that happens to authenticate to our server.

trans-unit.source: This is known as auto registration.
trans-unit.target: This is known as auto registration.

trans-unit.source: In production servers you wouldn’t want to let anyone in without first having them go through a registration process you decide.
trans-unit.target: In production servers you wouldn’t want to let anyone in without first having them go through a registration process you decide.

trans-unit.source: This is usually the pattern you see in consumer apps who allow you to register with Facebook but then ask you to fill out additional information.
trans-unit.target: This is usually the pattern you see in consumer apps who allow you to register with Facebook but then ask you to fill out additional information.

trans-unit.source: If this wasn’t a sample application, we could have just extracted the email from the token object that is returned and then asked them to fill out additional information.
trans-unit.target: If this wasn’t a sample application, we could have just extracted the email from the token object that is returned and then asked them to fill out additional information.

trans-unit.source: Since this is a test server we simply add them to the in-memory database.
trans-unit.target: Since this is a test server we simply add them to the in-memory database.

trans-unit.source: Next, let's add the methods that will allow us to keep track of the logged in users as required by Passport.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's add the methods that will allow us to keep track of the logged in users as required by Passport.

trans-unit.source: This includes serializing and deserializing the user's information:
trans-unit.target: This includes serializing and deserializing the user's information:

trans-unit.source: Next, let's add the code to load the express engine.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's add the code to load the express engine.

trans-unit.source: Here you see we use the default /views and /routes pattern that Express provides.
trans-unit.target: Here you see we use the default /views and /routes pattern that Express provides.

trans-unit.source: Finally, let's add the POST routes that will hand off the actual login requests to the `passport-azure-ad` engine:
trans-unit.target: Finally, let's add the POST routes that will hand off the actual login requests to the `passport-azure-ad` engine:

trans-unit.source: 4. Use Passport to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD
trans-unit.target: 4. Use Passport to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Your app is now properly configured to communicate with the v2.0 endpoint using the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.
trans-unit.target: Your app is now properly configured to communicate with the v2.0 endpoint using the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.

trans-unit.source: `passport-azure-ad` has taken care of all of the ugly details of crafting authentication messages, validating tokens from Azure AD, and maintaining user session.
trans-unit.target: `passport-azure-ad` has taken care of all of the ugly details of crafting authentication messages, validating tokens from Azure AD, and maintaining user session.

trans-unit.source: All that remains is to give your users a way to sign in, sign out, and gather additional info on the logged in user.
trans-unit.target: All that remains is to give your users a way to sign in, sign out, and gather additional info on the logged in user.

trans-unit.source: First, lets add the default, login, account, and logout methods to our `app.js` file:
trans-unit.target: First, lets add the default, login, account, and logout methods to our `app.js` file:

trans-unit.source: Let's review these in detail:
trans-unit.target: Let's review these in detail:

trans-unit.source: The `/` route will redirect to the index.ejs view passing the user in the request (if it exists)
trans-unit.target: The `/` route will redirect to the index.ejs view passing the user in the request (if it exists)

trans-unit.source: The `/account` route will first ***ensure we are authenticated*** (we implement that below) and then pass the user in the request so that we can get additional information about the user.
trans-unit.target: The `/account` route will first ***ensure we are authenticated*** (we implement that below) and then pass the user in the request so that we can get additional information about the user.

trans-unit.source: The `/login` route will call our azuread-openidconnect authenticator from `passport-azuread` and if that doesn't succeed will redirect the user back to /login
trans-unit.target: The `/login` route will call our azuread-openidconnect authenticator from `passport-azuread` and if that doesn't succeed will redirect the user back to /login

trans-unit.source: The `/logout` will simply call the logout.ejs (and route) which clears cookies and then return the user back to index.ejs
trans-unit.target: The `/logout` will simply call the logout.ejs (and route) which clears cookies and then return the user back to index.ejs

trans-unit.source: For the last part of `app.js`, let's add the EnsureAuthenticated method that is used in `/account` above.
trans-unit.target: For the last part of `app.js`, let's add the EnsureAuthenticated method that is used in `/account` above.

trans-unit.source: Finally, let's actually create the server itself in `app.js`:
trans-unit.target: Finally, let's actually create the server itself in `app.js`:

trans-unit.source: 5. Create the views and routes in express to display our user in the website
trans-unit.target: 5. Create the views and routes in express to display our user in the website

trans-unit.source: We have our `app.js` complete.
trans-unit.target: We have our `app.js` complete.

trans-unit.source: Now we simply need to add the routes and views that will show the information we get to the user as well as handle the `/logout` and `/login` routes we've created.
trans-unit.target: Now we simply need to add the routes and views that will show the information we get to the user as well as handle the `/logout` and `/login` routes we've created.

trans-unit.source: Create the `/routes/index.js` route under the root directory.
trans-unit.target: Create the `/routes/index.js` route under the root directory.

trans-unit.source: Create the `/routes/user.js` route under the root directory
trans-unit.target: Create the `/routes/user.js` route under the root directory

trans-unit.source: These simple routes will just pass along the request to our views, including the user if present.
trans-unit.target: These simple routes will just pass along the request to our views, including the user if present.

trans-unit.source: Create the `/views/index.ejs` view under the root directory.
trans-unit.target: Create the `/views/index.ejs` view under the root directory.

trans-unit.source: this is a simple page that will call our login and logout methods and allow us to grab account information.
trans-unit.target: this is a simple page that will call our login and logout methods and allow us to grab account information.

trans-unit.source: Notice that we can use the conditional `if (!user)` as the user being passed through in the request is evidence we have a logged in user.
trans-unit.target: Notice that we can use the conditional `if (!user)` as the user being passed through in the request is evidence we have a logged in user.

trans-unit.source: Create the `/views/account.ejs` view under the root directory so that we can view additional information that `passport-azuread` has put in the user request.
trans-unit.target: Create the `/views/account.ejs` view under the root directory so that we can view additional information that `passport-azuread` has put in the user request.

trans-unit.source: Finally, let's make this look pretty by adding a layout.
trans-unit.target: Finally, let's make this look pretty by adding a layout.

trans-unit.source: Create the '/views/layout.ejs' view under the root directory
trans-unit.target: Create the '/views/layout.ejs' view under the root directory

trans-unit.source: Finally, build and run your app!
trans-unit.target: Finally, build and run your app!

trans-unit.source: Run `node app.js` and navigate to `http://localhost:3000`
trans-unit.target: Run `node app.js` and navigate to `http://localhost:3000`

trans-unit.source: Sign in with either a personal Microsoft Account or a work or school account, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the /account list.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with either a personal Microsoft Account or a work or school account, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the /account list.

trans-unit.source: You now have a web app secured using industry standard protocols that can authenticate users with both their personal and work/school accounts.
trans-unit.target: You now have a web app secured using industry standard protocols that can authenticate users with both their personal and work/school accounts.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) [is provided as a .zip here](https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebApp-OpenIDConnect-nodejs/archive/complete.zip), or you can clone it from GitHub:

trans-unit.target: You can now move onto more advanced topics.
